messages.subject: Re: tsuba kantei 3 setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks, Jim, for the quick pointers re: Owari iron.  All good to know and remember.  I would imagine, too, that the particular period one is considering would
messages.messageBody:
Thanks, Jim, for the quick pointers re: Owari iron. All good to
know and remember. I would imagine, too, that the particular period
one is considering would play a role, too, no? I guess I would
expect that even Owari iron would be less "worked," less "dramatic"
with the coming of the Edo period...

On the weight of the Nobuiye, yes, if the plate is considerably
thinner than the rim, I could see where the tsuba wouldn't be quite
as heavy as it appears at first glance. Interesting thoughts, too,
on Nobuiye being the first to develop heavier guards. Is it correct
to suppose that the shift to the "two-hand swords" at the time of
Nobuiye might have been influential...? Thanks again, Jim.

Steven


--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@...>
wrote:
>
> Steven,
> Even though the rim is thick, the plate itself is fairly thin, so
it's not as heavy as you might think. Compared to earlier sukashi
and ita tsuba though, it is heavy. Nobuie was probably the first to
make heavier guards, but I'd have to think about that a bit more.
>
> Regarding Owari iron, go back through the previous kantei two
albums and as a group consider the metal, hammer work, tekkotsu
and "melted" finish. These are all typical of early Owari area
work. Also this album about tekkotsu
> http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/d4b0
are all Owari region.
>
> By comparison Kyoto iron has a softer look to it, more homogenous,
shows less modulation in the hammering, generally does not show
prominent tekkotsu or a melted finish (although some Ko-Shoami will
have this). Some would say more refined, others would say more
boring. Think Kyo-sukashi, Heianjo, Onin, Kaneie, etc. Usually it
is more of a brown color rather than blue-black of Owari (all
caveats about color in effect).
>
> It's probably not possible to explain without examples in hand,
but try to look carefully at the photos. Even with examples in hand
it takes some years of effort to see.
>
> Jim
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: steven
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Sunday, March 19, 2006 9:31 PM
> Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba kantei 3 setsumei
>
>
> Marvelous tsuba, Jim. I hadn't realized the piece was so
large. It must be very heavy.
> Fascinating details regarding the hitsuana, as well. I'd like
to ask if you could elaborate a
> bit on what is meant by "Owari iron." Exactly what gives it
away when one identifies a
> particular tsuba's iron as "clearly Owari"...? Thanks again,
Jim, for another great Kantei.
> Already looking forward to another...
>
> Steven
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba kantei 3 setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: Yes, on both sides.  Thanks Gordon. Jim ... From: Gordon Robson To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com Sent: Monday, March 20, 2006 8:04 PM Subject: Re:
messages.messageBody:
Yes, on both sides. Thanks Gordon.

Jim
----- Original Message -----
From: Gordon Robson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, March 20, 2006 8:04 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba kantei 3 setsumei


Thanks Jim, very fine tsuba with a wonderful signature. The motif is of
flowering plum branches, correct?

Gordon

On 2006/03/20, at 8:28, Jim Gilbert wrote:

> I have added scans of the other side of the tsuba to the folder below.
> I forgot to mention the dimensions again, so for the record they are
> 90.1 mm H x 84.1 mm W x 5.0 - 5.5 mm thick at the mimi.
>
> The maker is Nobuie and the signature is of the type now called
> futoji-mei 太字銘 (bold, thick). Within both the hanare and futoji-mei
> types there is considerable variation in the detail of the signatures.
> This example is not one of the more boldly executed futoji-mei. As
> Pete crypictically indicated, an oshigata of this guard is published
> in Nakamura Kakudayu and Akiyama Kyusaku's 1926 Nobuie Tsuba shu
> (#52). There the signature is described as sumari-mei 詰り銘 ("close
> packed"), which is one of the older terms now included within the
> futoji-mei type. This guard is described as futoji-mei in several
> later books and in the NBTHK's attribution.
>
> The hitsuana had not yet been filled when the oshigata was made. This
> guard was the property of the Okubo daimyo family in Odawara until it
> was sold in 1931, so the ana were likely filled by the new owner. It
> is unlikely that they are original to the plate given that they are
> made such that the guard would be mounted with the unsigned side as
> the front. The shapes of the hitsuana are unusual. It was clearly
> mounted with an o-kozuka, which are typically 18-20 mm wide (vs. the
> standard size of 14-15 mm). As Gordon mentioned, the small size of
> the kogai-ana suggests it was mounted with one of the narrow style
> ko-Mino kogai. The opening is too small to accommodate a standard
> 14-15 mm wide kogai.
>
> The early Edo period "betsujin" (different person) Nobuie work will
> lack the quality in the metal, tekkotsu, finish and carving. The
> plates are usually rather characterless and the working lacks
> subtlety. The late Edo period revival pieces do indeed try to emulate
> the finish of the originals and as Alan mentioned some do a fairly
> good job. In general, the working of the rim is a bit forced and
> overdone in these examples compared to the originals. They obviously
> will look young, but there is also a somewhat artificial quality to
> them. The same feeling comes from later copies of early Shino and
> Oribe ceramics.
>
> The metal, tekkotsu and yakite finish should lead to an Owari origin.
> Remember that Kaneie worked in Kyoto, and everything about his guards
> is in line with Kyoto methods and aesthetics.
>
> That's all I can think of at the moment.
>
> Jim
>
>
>
> The photos for kantei problem number three can be viewed here:
>
> http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/3108
>
> Jim
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
>
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba kantei 3 setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: Steven, Even though the rim is thick, the plate itself is fairly thin, so it s not as heavy as you might think.   Compared to earlier sukashi and ita tsuba
messages.messageBody:
Steven,
Even though the rim is thick, the plate itself is fairly thin, so it's not as heavy as you might think. Compared to earlier sukashi and ita tsuba though, it is heavy. Nobuie was probably the first to make heavier guards, but I'd have to think about that a bit more.

Regarding Owari iron, go back through the previous kantei two albums and as a group consider the metal, hammer work, tekkotsu and "melted" finish. These are all typical of early Owari area work. Also this album about tekkotsu
http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/d4b0 are all Owari region.

By comparison Kyoto iron has a softer look to it, more homogenous, shows less modulation in the hammering, generally does not show prominent tekkotsu or a melted finish (although some Ko-Shoami will have this). Some would say more refined, others would say more boring. Think Kyo-sukashi, Heianjo, Onin, Kaneie, etc. Usually it is more of a brown color rather than blue-black of Owari (all caveats about color in effect).

It's probably not possible to explain without examples in hand, but try to look carefully at the photos. Even with examples in hand it takes some years of effort to see.

Jim
----- Original Message -----
From: steven
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, March 19, 2006 9:31 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba kantei 3 setsumei


Marvelous tsuba, Jim. I hadn't realized the piece was so large. It must be very heavy.
Fascinating details regarding the hitsuana, as well. I'd like to ask if you could elaborate a
bit on what is meant by "Owari iron." Exactly what gives it away when one identifies a
particular tsuba's iron as "clearly Owari"...? Thanks again, Jim, for another great Kantei.
Already looking forward to another...

Steven


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

>
> I have added scans of the other side of the tsuba to the folder below. I forgot to
mention the dimensions again, so for the record they are 90.1 mm H x 84.1 mm W x 5.0 -
5.5 mm thick at the mimi.
>
> The maker is Nobuie and the signature is of the type now called futoji-mei å¤ªå­é
(bold, thick). Within both the hanare and futoji-mei types there is considerable variation
in the detail of the signatures. This example is not one of the more boldly executed
futoji-mei. As Pete crypictically indicated, an oshigata of this guard is published in
Nakamura Kakudayu and Akiyama Kyusaku's 1926 Nobuie Tsuba shu (#52). There the
signature is described as sumari-mei è©°ãé ("close packed"), which is one of the older
terms now included within the futoji-mei type. This guard is described as futoji-mei in
several later books and in the NBTHK's attribution.
>
> The hitsuana had not yet been filled when the oshigata was made. This guard was the
property of the Okubo daimyo family in Odawara until it was sold in 1931, so the ana were
likely filled by the new owner. It is unlikely that they are original to the plate given that
they are made such that the guard would be mounted with the unsigned side as the front.
The shapes of the hitsuana are unusual. It was clearly mounted with an o-kozuka, which
are typically 18-20 mm wide (vs. the standard size of 14-15 mm). As Gordon mentioned,
the small size of the kogai-ana suggests it was mounted with one of the narrow style ko-
Mino kogai. The opening is too small to accommodate a standard 14-15 mm wide kogai.
>
> The early Edo period "betsujin" (different person) Nobuie work will lack the quality in the
metal, tekkotsu, finish and carving. The plates are usually rather characterless and the
working lacks subtlety. The late Edo period revival pieces do indeed try to emulate the
finish of the originals and as Alan mentioned some do a fairly good job. In general, the
working of the rim is a bit forced and overdone in these examples compared to the
originals. They obviously will look young, but there is also a somewhat artificial quality to
them. The same feeling comes from later copies of early Shino and Oribe ceramics.
>
> The metal, tekkotsu and yakite finish should lead to an Owari origin. Remember that
Kaneie worked in Kyoto, and everything about his guards is in line with Kyoto methods
and aesthetics.
>
> That's all I can think of at the moment.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba kantei 3 setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: I have added scans of the other side of the tsuba to the folder below.  I forgot to mention the dimensions again, so for the record they are 90.1 mm H x 84.1
messages.messageBody:
I have added scans of the other side of the tsuba to the folder below. I forgot to mention the dimensions again, so for the record they are 90.1 mm H x 84.1 mm W x 5.0 - 5.5 mm thick at the mimi.

The maker is Nobuie and the signature is of the type now called futoji-mei 太字銘 (bold, thick). Within both the hanare and futoji-mei types there is considerable variation in the detail of the signatures. This example is not one of the more boldly executed futoji-mei. As Pete crypictically indicated, an oshigata of this guard is published in Nakamura Kakudayu and Akiyama Kyusaku's 1926 Nobuie Tsuba shu (#52). There the signature is described as sumari-mei 詰り銘 ("close packed"), which is one of the older terms now included within the futoji-mei type. This guard is described as futoji-mei in several later books and in the NBTHK's attribution.

The hitsuana had not yet been filled when the oshigata was made. This guard was the property of the Okubo daimyo family in Odawara until it was sold in 1931, so the ana were likely filled by the new owner. It is unlikely that they are original to the plate given that they are made such that the guard would be mounted with the unsigned side as the front. The shapes of the hitsuana are unusual. It was clearly mounted with an o-kozuka, which are typically 18-20 mm wide (vs. the standard size of 14-15 mm). As Gordon mentioned, the small size of the kogai-ana suggests it was mounted with one of the narrow style ko-Mino kogai. The opening is too small to accommodate a standard 14-15 mm wide kogai.

The early Edo period "betsujin" (different person) Nobuie work will lack the quality in the metal, tekkotsu, finish and carving. The plates are usually rather characterless and the working lacks subtlety. The late Edo period revival pieces do indeed try to emulate the finish of the originals and as Alan mentioned some do a fairly good job. In general, the working of the rim is a bit forced and overdone in these examples compared to the originals. They obviously will look young, but there is also a somewhat artificial quality to them. The same feeling comes from later copies of early Shino and Oribe ceramics.

The metal, tekkotsu and yakite finish should lead to an Owari origin. Remember that Kaneie worked in Kyoto, and everything about his guards is in line with Kyoto methods and aesthetics.

That's all I can think of at the moment.

Jim



The photos for kantei problem number three can be viewed here:

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/3108

Jim


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
